title: Separate to Collaborate: Dual-Stream Diffusion Model for Coordinated Piano Hand Motion Synthesis
author: Zihao Liu (Tsinghua University), Mingwen Ou (Tsinghua University), Zunnan Xu (Tsinghua University), Jiaqi Huang (Tsinghua University), Haonan Han (Tsinghua University), Ronghui Li (Tsinghua University), Xiu Li (Tsinghua University), ...
relevance_why: The proposed methods for generating coordinated hand motions from audio inputs could be leveraged in Haohe Liu's research on audio processing tasks, especially in applications involving music generation and restoration.
background: Generating realistic hand motions for piano performances from audio signals while maintaining the independence and coordination of both hands.
contribution: This paper introduces a dual-stream neural framework to solve the problem of synthesizing synchronized piano hand movements, achieving more natural and coordinated performances.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often used single-stream architectures that failed to account for the distinct roles and movements of each hand.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work utilizes independent diffusion models for each hand and an attention mechanism to enhance inter-hand coordination, resulting in more believable motion synthesis.

key_innovation: The implementation of a decoupled architecture with a Hand-Coordinated Asymmetric Attention mechanism that effectively balances hand independence and coordination.
real_world_impact: This method can significantly improve the realism of sessions in virtual piano performances or AI-powered music education systems, enhancing user experience and learning outcomes.
limitations: The authors do not mention any specific limitations.

new_terms.Hand-Coordinated Asymmetric Attention (H: **HCAA** is a mechanism within the model that allows for improved coordination between the left and right hand by emphasizing hand-specific features while suppressing common-mode noise.
